titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Elizabeth Harriet Thomson papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Bella Z. Berson

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers are composed of correspondence and project files which document Elizabeth Thomson's research and writing on the history of medicine. Additional material concerns her editorial and administrative work for John Fulton in the Yale University Department of the History of Medicine.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Elizabeth Harriet Thomson Papers (MS 1623). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in two series: I. Correspondence and Personal Papers, 1945-1990, II. Projects, 1950-1981.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Elizabeth Harriet Thomson was born on September 6, 1907, near Holland Patent, New York. After receiving her B.S. in 1911 from Simmons College, she worked as an editorial assistant at Mount Holyoke College and later at the National League of Nursing and in the Army Air Force. From 1945 until her retirement in 1972 she served as assistant in research at the Yale Medical Historical Library and then as research assistant and later research associate in the Yale University Department of the History of Medicine. Thomson helped John Fulton prepare a biography of Harvey Cushing and was his coauthor on Benjamin Silliman, 1779-1864, Pathfinder in American Science . In 1949, Thomson wrote Harvey Cushing: Surgeon, Author, Artist . She also served as editor of the Journal of the History of Medicine . Her biography of Fulton was unfinished at the time of her death on December 29, 1991.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers are composed of correspondence and project files which document Elizabeth Thomson's research and writing on the history of medicine. Additional material concerns her editorial and administrative work for John Fulton in the Yale University Department of the History of Medicine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence and personal papers of Elizabeth Thomson. The files are arranged alphabetically by record type.

Correspondence comprises the bulk of the series, though the correspondence itself is scattered. The files are arranged alphabetically and include exchanges with bibliophiles, students, family, and colleagues associated with John Fulton, which show the admixture of business and intellectual life with Thomson's social affairs. The letters from Fulton, William W. Francis of the Osler Library in Montreal, and Noel Poynter of the Wellcome Historical Medical Library in London are warmly personal but also relate to their work. There is also correspondence with Madeline Stanton and members of her family. Some writers, William W. Francis, for example, addressed letters jointly to Madeline Stanton and Thomson. These letters are divided between the Thomson Papers and the Madeline Stanton Papers (MS 1482).
The scant files of personal papers include biographical information in the form of tributes to Thomson on the occasion of her retirement and her obituary. There is also some family memorabilia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Project files, which are arranged chronologically, include Thomson's writings as well as materials for her organizational work on various tributes, commemorations, and celebrations at the Yale School of Medicine and in its Historical Library. Her contributions to the second edition of John Fulton's Selected Readings in the History of Physiology and her efforts associated with Madeline Stanton's Smith College Alumnae Medal are documented. Files of her writings contain book reviews, obituaries, correspondence and publicity for Harvey Cushing: Surgeon, Author, Artist , and notes for a biography of John Fulton. Photocopies of some chapters of the incomplete biography are available at the Yale University Cushing/Whitney Medical Historical Library.
